questions.text: Due to development defect of the hypobranchial eminence, which of the following cartilage of larynx may affected during development?
questions.solution:
• Epiglottis Development:
    • Origin: The epiglottis develops from the caudal part of the hypobranchial eminence.
    • A developmental defect in the hypobranchial eminence specifically affects the epiglottis, which is its primary derivative in the larynx.
  • Other Laryngeal Cartilages:
    • Arytenoid, Corniculate, and Cuneiform Cartilages: These develop from the fourth and sixth pharyngeal arches, not the hypobranchial eminence. Their development is unaffected by defects in the hypobranchial eminence.
  • All the cartilages of the larynx (e.g., thyroid, cricoid, arytenoids, corniculate and cuneiform) develop from mesenchyme of fourth and sixth pharyngeal arch, which is derived from neural crest cells.
  • The epiglottis develops from the caudal part of hypobranchial eminence.

Why Not Others:

  • Arytenoid (a): Develops from mesenchyme of the fourth and sixth pharyngeal arches, unrelated to the hypobranchial eminence.
  • Corniculate (b): Also derived from pharyngeal arch mesenchyme, independent of hypobranchial eminence defects.
  • Cuneiform (c): Like the others, forms from pharyngeal arches and is not impacted by hypobranchial eminence issues.

Key Takeaway: A defect in the hypobranchial eminence primarily affects the development of the epiglottis, while other laryngeal cartilages (arytenoid, corniculate, cuneiform) are unaffected because they develop from the pharyngeal arches.

choices.text: Respiration is not possible at this stage
Respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts are formed

questions.text: Which of the following developmental change is false about the canalicular stage of maturation of the lungs?
questions.solution:
• Respiration is not possible at this stage (False):
    • In the canalicular stage (16-26 weeks), respiration becomes possible by the end of the stage as respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and some alveolar sacs form, and the lung tissue becomes vascularized. (False statement)
  • Respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts are formed (True):
    • Formation of respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts characterizes this stage, enabling potential respiration.
  • Alveolar sacs are formed (True):
    • Few alveolar sacs begin to form during the canalicular stage, which is crucial for later gas exchange.
  • Lung tissue is well vascularized (True):
    • Vascularization of the lung tissue during this stage prepares it for efficient gas exchange later on.
  • Maturation of the lungs is divided into four stages/periods
    • Pseudoglandular stage: 5-16 weeks
    • Canalicular stage: 16-26 weeks
    • Terminal sac stage: 26 weeks to birth
    • Alveolar stage: 8 months to 8 years

Why Not Others:

  • Respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts are formed during this stage, making the option true.
  • Alveolar sacs start to form during the canalicular stage, making it true.
  • Lung tissue becomes well vascularized, supporting respiration towards the end of the stage, hence true.

Key Takeaway:

The canalicular stage (16-26 weeks) is critical as respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and some alveolar sacs form, with increasing vascularization, making respiration possible by the end of this stage.

choices.text: Smooth part of the right atrium
Smooth part of the right ventricle
Trabeculated part of the right ventricle
Trabeculated part of the right atrium

questions.text: Which of the following adult part of the adult heart is develops from the bulbus cordis?
questions.solution:
• Bulbus cordis forms the smooth part of the right ventricle(conus arteriosus) and the smooth part of the left ventricle (aortic vestibule).
  • Other regions:
    • Smooth part of the right atrium (sinus venosus origin)
    • Trabeculated parts of both atria and ventricles come from the primitive atrium and primitive ventricle

Fate of the embryonic dilatations of the primitive heart tube:


Why not others:

  • Smooth part of the right atrium: Originates from sinus venosus.
  • Trabeculated part of the right ventricle: Comes from the primitive ventricle.
  • Trabeculated part of the right atrium: Comes from the primitive atrium.

Key takeaway: The bulbus cordis contributes to the smooth parts of the ventricles (right - conus arteriosus, left - aortic vestibule).

questions.text: Each horn of sinus venosus receives all of the following veins, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Development of the Sinus Venosus:
    • The sinus venosus is the venous end of the heart tube and is crucial for the development of the heart.
    • It consists of a small transverse body and two horns (right and left).
  • Vitelline vein (True):
    • Drains blood from the yolk sac, supplying nutrients to the embryo.
    • Forms the hepatic portal vein as it persists into postnatal life.
  • Umbilical vein (True):
    • Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the developing fetus.
    • Plays a vital role in fetal circulation and becomes the round ligament of the liver after birth.
  • Pulmonary vein (False):
    • The pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs directly into the left atrium.
    • They are not involved in the sinus venosus during early development but rather form later in the developmental process.
    • Significance: Their separation from the sinus venosus is crucial for establishing the systemic and pulmonary circuits.
  • Common cardinal vein (True):
    • Drains blood from the body wall into the sinus venosus, integrating systemic venous return into the developing heart.
    • Contributes to the formation of the superior and inferior vena cavae in postnatal life.
  • Each horn of sinus venosus receives three primitive veins:
    • The vitelline vein from the yolk sac
    • The umbilical vein from the placenta
    • The common cardinal vein from the body wall

Why Not Others:

  • A. Vitelline vein: This vein connects to the yolk sac, facilitating nutrient transfer during embryonic development.
  • B. Umbilical vein: This vein is crucial for delivering oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • D. Common cardinal vein: This vein brings blood from the body to the sinus venosus, essential for venous return.
  • C. Pulmonary vein: This is not connected to the sinus venosus; it drains directly into the left atrium and is vital for oxygenation post-birth.

Key Takeaway:

The pulmonary vein is the only vein listed that does not connect to the sinus venosus; it directly enters the left atrium, while the vitelline, umbilical, and common cardinal veins all play integral roles in the early development of the heart and venous system.

choices.text: Pulmonary stenosis, Overriding of aorta, ventricular septal defect, Hypertrophy of left ventricle
Pulmonary stenosis, Overriding of aorta, ventricular septal defect, Hypertrophy of right ventricle
Pulmonary stenosis, Overriding of aorta, atrial septal defect, Hypertrophy of right ventricle
Pulmonary stenosis, Overriding of aorta, atrial septal defect, Hypertrophy of left ventricle

questions.text: Fallot's tetralogy is combination of:
questions.solution:
• Overview of Fallot's Tetralogy:
    • Common congenital cyanotic heart disease, affecting approximately 9.6 per 10,000 births.
    • Results from an unequal division of the conus due to the anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum.
  • Four Key Components:
    • Pulmonary Stenosis:
      • Narrowing of the pulmonary trunk, obstructing blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs.
    • Overriding Aorta:
      • Aorta is positioned directly over the ventricular septal defect (VSD), straddling both ventricles.
    • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
      • A defect in the interventricular septum, allowing for shunting of blood between the left and right ventricles.
    • Hypertrophy of the Right Ventricle:
      • Compensatory hypertrophy due to increased pressure from right ventricular outflow obstruction.
    • Pathophysiology:
      • The combination leads to a right-to-left shunt of blood, resulting in cyanosis(bluish skin due to low oxygen levels).
      • Affects overall oxygenation, particularly during exertion or crying.
  • Fallot's tetralogy:
    • Stenosis of pulmonary trunk
    • Overriding aorta
    • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
    • Hypertrophy of the right ventricle

Why Not Others:

  • A. Hypertrophy of left ventricle:
    • Incorrect; hypertrophy occurs in the right ventricle due to increased pressure, not the left.
  • C. Atrial septal defect:
    • Incorrect; Fallot's tetralogy specifically involves a ventricular septal defect, not an atrial septal defect.
  • D. Atrial septal defect and hypertrophy of left ventricle:
    • Incorrect; both components are not part of the classic definition of Fallot's tetralogy.

Key Takeaway:

Fallot's tetralogy consists of pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and hypertrophy of the right ventricle, leading to cyanotic manifestations due to right-to-left shunting.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is derived from left sixth arterial arch?
questions.solution:
• Development of the Arterial System:
    • Arteries develop from two main sources:
      • Pharyngeal (aortic) arch arteries: Supply the head and neck region.
      • Dorsal aorta: Supplies the rest of the body.
    • Each pharyngeal arch is supplied by an artery derived from the aortic sac, which gives rise to six pairs of aortic arch arteries.
    • The fifth pair is usually not retained, leaving the first, second, third, fourth, and sixth arches
  • Derivatives of the Aortic Arches:
    • First Arch:Maxillary artery
    • Second Arch: Hyaloid and stapedial arteries (fetal life only)
    • Third Arch: Common carotid artery (Option B)
    • Fourth Arch:
      • Left side: Part of the arch of aorta (Option D)
      • Right side: Proximal part of the right subclavian artery
    • Fifth Arch: Disappears
    • Sixth Arch:
      • Left side: Left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus (Option C)
      • Right side: Right pulmonary artery
    • Importance of the Ductus Arteriosus:
      • A critical structure allowing blood to bypass the non-functioning fetal lungs, connecting the pulmonary trunk to the aorta.
      • Typically closes after birth, becoming the ligamentum arteriosum.

Derivatives of arterial arches:


Source of development of main arteries


Why Not Others:

  • A. Left subclavian artery:
    • Incorrect; derives from the left seventh cervical intersegmental artery, not the sixth arch.
  • B. Left common carotid artery:
    • Incorrect; originates from the third arch artery.
  • D. Arch of aorta:
    • Incorrect; develops from the left fourth arch artery and the aortic sac.

Key Takeaway: The left sixth arterial arch gives rise to the ductus arteriosus, facilitating fetal circulation by allowing blood to bypass the lungs, alongside the left pulmonary artery.

questions.text: Which of the embryonic vein does not take part in the formation of the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
• Development of the Inferior Vena Cava (IVC):
    • The IVC is the largest vein in the body, developing from six embryonic components.
    • From caudal to cranial, these components include:
      • Right posterior cardinal vein (Option B): Forms part of the sacrocardinal segment of the IVC.
      • Right supracardinal vein (Option C): Contributes to the caudal part of the IVC.
      • Right subcardinal vein (Option D): Involved in forming the renal segment of the IVC.
      • Anastomoses: These include connections between the right supracardinal and subcardinal veins, and a channel connecting the right subcardinal vein with the right hepatocardiac channel.
    • Role of Components:
      • Right common cardinal vein (Option A): Does not participate in IVC formation. It primarily contributes to the formation of the superior vena cava (SVC).
      • The right hepatocardiac channel forms the terminal segment of the IVC, eventually opening into the right atrium.
  • Development of IVC:
  • Inferior vena cava develops from:
    • Anastomoses of right and left posterior cardinal veins
    • Right supracardinal vein
    • Right suprasubcardinal anastomosis
    • Right subcardinal vein
    • New channel between right subcardinal and cranial part of right vitelline vein
    • Right hepatocardiac channel

Why Not Others:

  • B. Right posterior cardinal vein:
    • Correctly contributes to the formation of the IVC.
  • C. Right supracardinal vein:
    • Plays a role in the development of the IVC.
  • D. Right subcardinal vein:
    • Also contributes to IVC development.

Key Takeaway:

The right common cardinal vein does not participate in forming the inferior vena cava, while the right posterior cardinal, right supracardinal, and right subcardinal veins are essential components in its development.

questions.text: All of the following structures derived from dorsal mesogastrium, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Fate of Mesogastrium:
    • The abdominal part of the foregut is supported by both ventral and dorsal mesenteries:
      • Ventral Mesogastrium: Involved in liver ligament formation.
      • Dorsal Mesogastrium: Supports structures related to the stomach and spleen.
    • Structures Derived from Dorsal Mesogastrium:
      • Greater Omentum (Option A): Elongates to form a protective layer over the intestines.
      • Gastrophrenic Ligament (Option B): Connects the stomach to the diaphragm, formed from the cranial part.
      • Gastrospenic Ligament (Option C): Connects the stomach to the spleen, derived from the ventral part.
    • What Does Not Derive from Dorsal Mesogastrium:
      • Lesser Omentum (Option D): Forms from the ventral mesogastrium, connecting the stomach and liver.

  • Derivatives of msogastrium:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Greater omentum:
    • Derived from the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • B. Gastrophrenic ligament:
    • Derived from the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • C. Gastrospenic ligament:
    • Derived from the dorsal mesogastrium.

Key Takeaway:

The lesser omentum originates from the ventral mesogastrium, while the greater omentum, gastrophrenic ligament, and gastrospenic ligament arise from the dorsal mesogastrium.

choices.text: Total rotation of 270° in clockwise direction (first 180° rotation occurs outside the abdominal cavity and remaining 90° rotation occurs within the abdominal cavity)
Total rotation of 270° in anticlockwise direction (first 180° rotation occurs within outside the abdominal cavity and remaining 90° rotation occurs within the abdominal cavity)
Total rotation of 270° in clockwise direction (first 90° rotation occurs outside the abdominal cavity and remaining 180° rotation occurs within the abdominal cavity)
Total rotation of 270° in anticlockwise direction (first 90° rotation occurs within outside the abdominal cavity and remaining 180° rotation occurs within the abdominal cavity)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the rotation of midgut loop?
questions.solution:
• Midgut Rotation Overview:
    • The midgut loop undergoes a critical rotation during development as herniated intestinal loops return to the abdominal cavity.
    • This rotation helps establish the final positions and relationships of the intestines.
  • Rotation Details:
    • The process begins at the end of the third month of intrauterine life (IUL) when the intestinal loops begin to retract into the abdominal cavity.
    • Before rotation, the midgut segments lie in a vertical plane due to their connection to the superior mesenteric artery.
  • Rotation Sequence:
    • First 90° Anticlockwise Rotation: Occurs outside the abdominal cavity at the umbilicus(This is a key point).
    • Second 90° Anticlockwise Rotation: Occurs within the abdominal cavity, leading to the jejunum and ileum positioning behind the superior mesenteric artery.
    • Third 90° Anticlockwise Rotation: Further establishes the cecum and appendix on the right side below the liver.

Key points:

  • Rotation of midgut:
    • In order to return in the abdominal cavity, the midgut loop undergoes rotation of 90° in anticlockwise direction thrice.
    • Thus, there is a total rotation of 270°.
    • First 90° rotation occurs within umbilicus (outside the abdominal cavity). Remaining 180° rotation occurs within the abdominal cavity.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Clockwise direction (180° outside): Incorrect as the rotation is anticlockwise.
  • B. Anticlockwise but 180° outside: Incorrect since the first rotation is only 90° outside.
  • C. Clockwise (90° outside, 180° inside): Incorrect because the total rotation is anticlockwise.

Key Takeaway:

The midgut loop rotates 270° in an anticlockwise direction, with the first 90° rotation occurring outside the abdominal cavity, followed by 180° rotation within the cavity, crucial for establishing intestinal relationships.

choices.text: Herniation of midgut bowel loops fail to return in abdominal cavity later
It has genetic basis and associated with other anomalies
Covered by peritoneum, wharton's jelly and amnion
It may gets reduced on its own within 2-3 years of life

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the congenital umbilical hernia?
questions.solution:
• Exomphalos/Omphalocele:
    • Results from failure of bowel loops to return to the abdominal cavity after physiological herniation.
    • Associated with genetic anomalies, including cardiac and neural tube defects.
    • Covered by peritoneum, Wharton's jelly, and amnion.
    • Option A & C are features of omphalocele, not congenital umbilical hernia.
  • Congenital Umbilical Hernia:
    • Herniation occurs through a weak umbilical openingdue to improper closure.
    • Covered by peritoneum, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.
    • It can self-resolve within 2-3 years(Option D).
  • The differences between the omphalocele and congenital umbilical hernia:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Herniation fails to return later: This describes omphalocele, not umbilical hernia.
  • C. Covered by Wharton's jelly and amnion: True for omphalocele, not congenital umbilical hernia.
  • D. Reduced on its own: True, but Option B is the more complete and correct answer regarding genetic association.

Key Takeaway:

Congenital umbilical hernia is often self-resolving with no genetic basis, while omphalocele has a genetic component and is associated with other anomalies, making it a more serious condition.

choices.text: At the beginning of the third week
At the beginning of the fourth week
At the beginning of the fifth week
At the beginning of the sixth week

questions.text: During which period of time the pronephros appears in the developing embryo?
questions.solution:
• Pronephros:
    • Appears in the fourth week of development, specifically in the cervical region.
    • It is non functional in humans and regresses completely, except for its duct, which contributes to the mesonephric duct.
    • Option B is correct because it accurately represents the timing of its appearance.
  • Mesonephros:
    • Appears at the end of the fourth week and is functional for a short period.
  • Metanephros:
    • Forms in the third month and persists as the permanent kidney.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Beginning of third week: Too early; nephrogenesis starts in the fourth week.
  • C & D. Fifth and sixth weeks: By this time, the mesonephros is already functional, and the pronephros has regressed.

Key Takeaway:

The pronephros forms in the fourth week, plays no significant role in humans, and is succeeded by the mesonephros and metanephros, which contribute to the development of the urinary system.

questions.text: Median umbilical ligament is a remnant of:
questions.solution:
• Median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the allantois.
  • During fetal development, the allantois connects the developing bladder to the umbilicus.
  • After birth, the allantois obliterates and forms a fibrous cord called the urachus, which later becomes the median umbilical ligament.

Remnants of Fetal Structures:

  • Vitellointestinal duct (Option A): Remnant is Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Allantois (Option B): Becomes the median umbilical ligament.
  • Umbilical artery (Option C): Forms the superior vesicle artery and medial umbilical ligament.
  • Left umbilical vein (Option D): Becomes the ligamentum teres hepatis.
  • Remnants of fetal structures after birth:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Vitellointestinal duct: Forms Meckel's diverticulum, not the median umbilical ligament.
  • C. Left umbilical artery: Forms the superior vesical artery and medial umbilical ligament.
  • D. Left umbilical vein: Forms ligamentum teres hepatis.

Key Takeaway:

The median umbilical ligament is a fibrous remnant of the allantois, part of the urinary development system.

questions.text: Which of the following is remnant of the mesonephric duct in the female?
questions.solution:
• Gartner's duct is the remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females.
    • It lies between the two layers of the broad ligament alongside the uterus.
    • In males, the mesonephric duct forms structures such as the vas deferens, but in females, this duct largely regresses, leaving behind Gartner's duct.
    • This remnant can occasionally form Gartner's cysts, which may cause clinical concerns.

Other Remnants of Mesonephric System:

  • Epoophoron (Option A):
    • A remnant of the mesonephric tubules, not the duct itself.
    • It is found near the ovary and corresponds to the efferent ductules of the testis in males.
  • Paroophoron (Option B):
    • Another remnant of mesonephric tubules.
    • Located between the ovary and uterus, but it is a vestigial structure.
  • Infundibular part of uterine tube (Option D):
    • Derived from the paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct, not the mesonephric duct.
    • This structure forms part of the fallopian tubes.

Key points:

  • In females, the paramesonephric ducts form:
    • Uterine tubes
    • Uterus
    • Upper part of vagina
  • In females, the mesonephric ducts & tubules form:
    • Epoophoron
    • Paroophoron
    • Gartner's duct

Why Not Others?

  • Epoophoron:
    • Comes from mesonephric tubules, not the duct itself.
    • It is found in the mesovarium and corresponds to structures in the male reproductive system.
  • Paroophoron:
    • A remnant of mesonephric tubules, not the duct.
    • It is a minor vestigial structure, and its clinical relevance is minimal.
  • Infundibular part of uterine tube:
    • Formed by the paramesonephric duct, not the mesonephric duct, so it doesn't qualify here.

Key Takeaway:

The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the mesonephric duct in females, typically found within the broad ligament. It may result in Gartner's cysts, while the epoophoron and paroophoron are remnants of mesonephric tubules.

questions.text: Which of the following is the derivative of the mullerian tubercle in the male?
questions.solution:
• Müllerian tubercle is an embryonic structure that gives rise to the seminal colliculus (verumontanum) in males.
    • The seminal colliculus is a small elevation on the posterior wall of the prostatic urethra, serving as the location where the ejaculatory ducts open.
  • In females, the Müllerian tubercle forms the hymen, a thin membrane covering the vaginal opening.

Embryonic structures and their homologous adult derivatives in male and female:


Key points:


Why Not Others?

  • B. Prostatic utricle:
    • Though derived from Müllerian duct remnants, it is not from the Müllerian tubercle specifically
  • C. Seminal vesicle:
    • Derived from the mesonephric duct, involved in producing a significant portion of semen.
  • D. Paradidymis:
    • A vestigial remnant of mesonephric tubules, unrelated to the Müllerian system.

Key Takeaway:

The Müllerian tubercle in males gives rise to the seminal colliculus (verumontanum), a small elevation in the prostatic urethra, while in females, it forms the hymen.

questions.text: The result of failure of fusion of the first and second branchial arches leads to development of:
questions.solution:
• Pre-auricular sinus results from failure of fusion of the first and second branchial arches.
    • It presents as small pits near the external ear.
    • These sinuses may become infected and require surgical excision.
  • Close proximity to the facial nerve makes the surgical procedure demanding, as the sinus can sometimes extend deeply towards the external acoustic meatus.
  • Preauricular sulcus:
    • The result of failure of fusion of the first and second branchial arches.
    • Clinically, pre-auricular sinuses may become chronically infected and require surgical excision.
    • This may be technically demanding, given the close proximity to the facial nerve and auricular tubercles around the dorsal end of the first branchial cleft.

Why Not Others?

  • A. Branchial cyst:
    • Forms from remnants of the second, third, and fourth pharyngeal clefts, not from failure of fusion of the first and second arches.
  • C. Diminutive ear:
    • Microtia is an isolated congenital anomaly related to external ear development, not directly associated with branchial arch fusion failure.
  • D. Satiro's ear:
    • A deformity of the auricle due to cartilage abnormalities, not due to branchial arch fusion

Key Takeaway:

The pre-auricular sinus is the result of the failure of fusion of the first and second branchial arches, leading to the formation of small pits near the ear, which may become infected and need surgical excision.

questions.text: Which of the following structure of the eye develops from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
• Lens(Option A) develops from the surface ectoderm of the head.
    • The surface ectoderm also forms the anterior epithelium of the cornea.
  • Neuroectoderm forms structures like the retina, optic nerve, and epithelium of the iris (Option B).
  • Mesoderm contributes to the development of sclera (Option C) and vascular coats of the eye.
  • Neural crest cells form the choroid, sclera, and corneal epithelium, and vitreous body (Option D) originates from mesoderm.

Adult components of eye derived from various embryonic structures:


Key points:

  • The eye develops from four sources:
    • Neuroectoderm of forebrain
    • Surface ectoderm of head
    • Mesoderm between neuroectoderm of forebrain and surface ectoderm of head
    • Neural crest cells

Why Not Others?

  • B. Epithelium of iris:
    • Derived from neuroectoderm, not surface ectoderm.
  • C. Sclera:
    • Arises from mesoderm and neural crest cells, not surface ectoderm.
  • D. Vitreous body:
    • Comes from mesoderm, not surface ectoderm.

Key Takeaway:

The lens is derived from surface ectoderm, while other structures such as the sclera, iris epithelium, and vitreous body come from neuroectoderm, mesoderm, and neural crest cells respectively.

questions.text: At the third week of intrauterine life the Rathke's pouch gives rise to development of which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
• The pituitary gland develops from two distinct parts:
    • Adenohypophysis(anterior pituitary) develops from Rathke's pouch, which is an ectodermal evagination from the roof of the primitive oral cavity (stomodeum). Rathke's pouch forms around the third week of intrauterine life.
    • Neurohypophysis(posterior pituitary) arises from the neuroectoderm of the hypothalamus (floor of the third ventricle).
  • Adenohypophysis gives rise to:
    • Pars anterior(anterior lobe), which forms the major part of the anterior pituitary.
    • Pars intermedia, which is formed from the posterior wall of Rathke's pouch.
    • Pars tuberalis, an upward extension along the infundibular stalk.
  • Neurohypophysis forms the pars posterior (posterior lobe/pars nervosa) and infundibulum.

Why not others:

  • Thyroid gland(Option A) develops from the thyroglossal duct, an endodermal structure.
  • Parathyroid gland(Option B) arises from the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • Pineal gland(Option C) develops from a diverticulum in the roof of the third ventricle.

Key takeaway: Rathke's pouch forms the adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary), while the other structures develop from different embryological origins.

questions.text: Developmental defect in the neural crest cells will give rise to defective development of all of the following structures, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Neural crest cells originate from the neurectoderm and give rise to several structures, including:
    • Dorsal root ganglia(Option A)
    • Sensory ganglia of cranial nerves
    • Autonomic ganglia(Option B)
    • Adrenal medullaand chromaffin tissue (Option D)
    • Melanocytes and Schwann cells
  • The adrenal cortex(Option C), however, is derived from the mesoderm (specifically, the coelomic epithelium). Hence, a defect in neural crest cells does not affect the adrenal cortex.

Key points:

  • The neural crest cells differentiate to form cells of
    • Dorsal root ganglia, sensory ganglia of cranial nerves & autonomic ganglia
    • Adrenal medulla
    • Chromaffin tissue
    • Melanocytes
    • Schwann cells

Why not others:

  • Dorsal root ganglia and autonomic ganglia are derived from neural crest cells, which are crucial for sensory and autonomic nervous system development.
  • Chromaffin tissue, which is part of the adrenal medulla, is also derived from neural crest cells.
  • The adrenal cortex comes from the mesoderm, making it the correct exception in this case.

Key takeaway: Defects in neural crest cells affect structures like dorsal root ganglia, autonomic ganglia, and chromaffin tissue, but not the adrenal cortex, which is mesodermal in origin.

questions.text: At 24 weeks of intrauterine life the spinal cord present upto which of the following vertebral level?
questions.solution:
• Positional changes of the spinal cord occur due to differential growth between the spinal cord and vertebral column:
    • At 8 weeks, the spinal cord spans the entire length of the vertebral canal.
    • By week 18, it terminates at S3(Option B).
    • At 24 weeks, it ends at S1(Option C).
    • At birth, it terminates at L3(Option D).
    • In adults, the cord ends at L1.
  • Termination of spinal cord in relation to vertebral canal at various stages of development:

  • Termination of spinal cord in relation to vertebral canal at various stages of development:
    • Up to the 3rd month of intrauterine development, the spinal cord extends throughout the entire length of the vertebral canal.
    • At week 18, the lower end of spinal cord ends at S3 vertebrae.
    • At week 24, the lower end of spinal cord ends at S1 vertebrae.
    • At birth, the lower end of spinal cord ends at the level of L3 vertebrae.
  • The knowledge of these variations in the vertebral level of the lower end of the cord is important to avoid injury to the cord while performing lumbar puncture, especially in children.

Why not others:

  • Entire length(Option A) is accurate for the third month of intrauterine life.
  • S3(Option B) is accurate for 18 weeks of development.
  • L3(Option D) is correct at birth, not 24 weeks.

Key takeaway: At 24 weeks, the spinal cord terminates at S1, and positional changes are crucial for avoiding spinal cord injury during procedures like lumbar punctures.

questions.text: The body of the pineal gland derived from which of the following secondary brain vesicle?
questions.solution:
• Brain development begins from the neural tube's cranial end, which expands into primary brain vesicles by the end of the 4th week.
  • The prosencephalon(forebrain), one of the primary vesicles, later divides into telencephalon and diencephalon in the 5th week, forming secondary brain vesicles.
  • Diencephalon gives rise to major structures such as:
    • Thalamus
    • Hypothalamus
    • Subthalamus
    • Epithalamus, which includes the pineal gland.
  • The pineal gland begins its development as a diverticulum from the roof of the diencephalon, specifically from the epithalamus during the 7th week.
  • By birth, the pineal gland plays a critical role in producing melatonin, a hormone regulating circadian rhythms.

Adult derivatives of brain vesicles:


Why not others:

  • Telencephalon(Option A) forms the cerebral hemispheres and contributes to the lateral ventricles, not the pineal gland.
  • Mesencephalon(Option C) gives rise to the midbrain and contributes to the cerebral aqueduct.
  • Metencephalon(Option D) develops into the pons and cerebellum, which are part of the hindbrain.

Key takeaway: The diencephalon is responsible for the development of the pineal gland, which regulates circadian rhythms and is part of the epithalamus.
